subject: polity
title: Conflicts between Fundamental Rights and DPSPs

fundamentalTension: **FRs**: Individual liberty, property rights, negative obligations ('State shall NOT')
**DPSPs**: Social welfare, equitable distribution, positive obligations ('State SHALL')
**Conflict arises**: When implementing DPSP (social welfare) requires restricting FR (individual liberty)
examples: **Land reforms** (DPSP Art 39(b) - equitable distribution) vs **Right to property** (was FR Art 31, now Art 300A)
**Nationalization** (DPSP Art 39(b) - common good) vs **Right to trade** (FR Art 19(1)(g))
**Reservation** (DPSP Art 46 - SC/ST welfare) vs **Right to equality** (FR Art 14, 16)
**Labor laws** (DPSP Art 43 - living wage) vs **Freedom of contract** (FR Art 19(1)(g))
coreIssue: **FR philosophy**: Liberal individualism - protect individual from State
**DPSP philosophy**: Socialism/welfare - State intervention for common good
**Balance needed**: Too much FR → Inequality; Too much DPSP → Tyranny
content.examTips: **Most asked**: Why conflict arises? Because FRs protect individual liberty (negative) while DPSPs require State intervention for welfare (positive). Classic example: Property rights (FR) vs Land reforms (DPSP).

articles.title: State of Madras v Champakam Dorairajan (1951)

facts: **Year**: 1951 (first major FR vs DPSP conflict case)
**Issue**: Madras government reserved seats in medical/engineering colleges for **backward classes, SCs, STs** based on caste
**Reservation exceeded merit**: Some reserved candidates had lower marks than general category
**Legal basis**: Government justified under Art 46 (DPSP - protect SC/ST)
**Champakam Dorairajan**: Brahmin student denied admission despite higher marks; challenged reservation
scJudgment: **Reasoning**: Art 37 explicitly states DPSPs are **non-justiciable**; FRs are **justiciable** (enforceable through Art 32)
**Cannot violate FR** (Art 15(1), 29(2) - no discrimination) to implement DPSP (Art 46)
**State's power limited**: Cannot make laws violating FRs even if for DPSP implementation
Reservation struck down as violating Art 15(1) (no discrimination), Art 29(2) (merit-based admission)
aftermath: **1st Constitutional Amendment 1951** passed immediately after judgment
**Art 15(4) added**: State can make special provisions for SCs, STs, backward classes
**Art 15(4) is exception to Art 15(1)**: Permits reservation without violating equality
Converted DPSP goal (Art 46) into **constitutional exception** to FR
significance: **First clear ruling**: FRs have primacy over DPSPs
**Led to amendment**: 1st Amendment changed constitutional balance
**Established principle**: DPSPs cannot override justiciable FRs
**But not final word**: Later cases (Kesavananda, Minerva Mills) modified this
content.examTips: **Most asked case**: Champakam (1951) held **FRs prevail over DPSPs**. Led to **1st Amendment** adding Art 15(4) (reservation permitted). Remember: First major FR-DPSP conflict; FR won; Legislature amended Constitution.

articles.title: Kesavananda Bharati v State of Kerala (1973)

facts: **Issue**: Kerala Land Reforms Act - acquired property of Kesavananda Bharati's mutt (monastery)
**Challenge**: Violation of right to property (then FR Art 31)
**Bigger issue**: Can Parliament **amend Constitution** to give DPSP primacy over FR? (24th, 25th, 29th Amendments validity challenged)
**Central question**: Unlimited amendment power or limitations?
scJudgment: **7:6 majority**: Parliament **cannot destroy basic features** of Constitution
**Basic structure includes**: Supremacy of Constitution, Rule of law, Judicial review, Separation of powers, **Balance between FRs and DPSPs**
**FRs and DPSPs together form basic structure**: Neither absolute supremacy
**Harmony needed**: Both are integral; Cannot sacrifice one completely for other
onFRvsDPSP: **Moved away from Champakam**: Not just 'FRs prevail'
**New approach**: **Harmonious construction** - balance both FRs and DPSPs
**Both important**: FRs for individual liberty; DPSPs for social justice
**Constitutional scheme**: Combination of FRs (means) and DPSPs (ends) creates 'Conscience of Constitution'
**Amendment power**: Can amend FRs to implement DPSPs, BUT cannot destroy basic structure
significance: **Most important case** in Indian constitutional law
**FR-DPSP balance**: Part of basic structure; Both equally important
**Overruled implicit**: Champakam's absolute FR primacy modified to balance approach
content.examTips: **MOST CRITICAL CASE**: Kesavananda (1973) - Basic Structure doctrine. **Balance between FRs and DPSPs** is part of basic structure. Neither absolute supremacy. Harmonious construction needed. 13-judge bench, 7:6 verdict.

articles.title: Minerva Mills v Union of India (1980)

facts: • Extended Art 31C to **ALL DPSPs** (originally only Art 39(b), (c))
• Added clause: Laws implementing DPSPs **cannot be challenged** on ground of violating Art 14, 19, 31
• Amended Art 368: No amendment can be questioned in any court on any ground
**Effect**: Made DPSPs supreme; Removed judicial review
scJudgment: **5-judge bench struck down** parts of 42nd Amendment
**Art 31C extension (to all DPSPs) struck down**: Violates basic structure
**Reasoning**: Balance between FRs and DPSPs is **basic feature**; Cannot give DPSPs absolute primacy
**Art 31C limited**: Valid only for Art 39(b), (c) (socialist DPSPs); Not for all DPSPs
**Art 368 clause struck down**: Judicial review cannot be removed; Basic structure protected
famousQuote: **Justice Bhagwati**: '*The Indian Constitution is founded on the bedrock of the balance between Parts III and IV*'
**'Two lungs' analogy**: Constitution has **two lungs - FRs and DPSPs**; Both essential for life of Constitution
Cannot let one lung collapse to save the other
Harmony and balance between FRs and DPSPs is essence of Constitution
principles: **Balance is key**: FRs and DPSPs must be balanced; Neither can have absolute supremacy
**Limited primacy**: Art 31C valid only for Art 39(b), (c) (equitable distribution); Not blanket supremacy to all DPSPs
**Judicial review intact**: Courts can examine if law genuinely implements DPSP or uses it as pretext to violate FR
**Democracy protected**: Emergency-era attempt to make DPSPs supreme failed
significance: **Limited Art 31C**: Scope reduced; Only Art 39(b), (c) covered
**Judicial independence**: Courts can review FR-DPSP balance
content.examTips: **MOST IMPORTANT FR-DPSP case**: Minerva Mills (1980) - Balance between FRs and DPSPs is basic feature. **'Two lungs'** analogy. Art 31C extension to all DPSPs struck down (now valid only for Art 39(b), (c)). Reinforced harmonious construction.

provision: **Purpose**: Give **priority to DPSP** implementation over FR
**Original scope**: Laws implementing **Art 39(b), (c)** (socialist principles - equitable distribution, common good)
**Protection**: Such laws cannot be challenged on ground of violating Art 14 (equality), Art 19 (freedoms)
**Rationale**: Enable land reforms, nationalization without FR challenges
art39bAndC: **Art 39(b)**: Ownership and control of **material resources** distributed for **common good**
**Art 39(c)**: Economic system does not result in **concentration of wealth** and means of production
Both are **socialist DPSPs** - Basis for nationalization, land reforms
42ndAmendmentChange: **42nd Amendment 1976** (Emergency period): Extended Art 31C to **ALL DPSPs**
**New clause**: Laws implementing **any DPSP** protected from FR challenge
**Effect**: Made all DPSPs supreme over FRs; Drastically changed constitutional balance
**Intent**: Give government free hand to implement socialist policies without judicial interference
minervaMillsReversal: **Minerva Mills (1980)**: SC struck down 42nd Amendment extension
**Reasoning**: Giving all DPSPs primacy over FRs destroys basic structure
**Current status**: Art 31C valid **only for Art 39(b), (c)** - NOT for all DPSPs
**Limited protection**: Only socialist economic DPSPs have some primacy; Not social/Gandhian DPSPs
currentScope: Laws implementing **Art 39(b), (c)** cannot be challenged on ground of violating **Art 14, 19** (but can be challenged on Art 21, other FRs)
**Bank nationalization**, land reforms, MRTP Act, etc. protected under Art 31C
Courts can still examine if law **genuinely** implements Art 39(b), (c) or uses it as pretext
content.examTips: **Art 31C**: Added by 25th Amendment 1971. Originally protected laws implementing Art 39(b), (c). 42nd Amendment extended to ALL DPSPs (struck down by Minerva Mills). **Current**: Valid only for Art 39(b), (c) vs Art 14, 19.

article31A: **Purpose**: Protect **land reform laws** from FR challenges
**Scope**: Laws providing for acquisition of estates, zamindari abolition, management of property by State
**Protection**: Cannot be challenged on ground of violating Art 14 (equality), Art 19 (freedoms), Art 31 (property - now repealed)
**Background**: Post-Champakam case; Enable land reforms (DPSP Art 39(b)) without FR obstacles
article31B: **Ninth Schedule**: Created Ninth Schedule - list of Acts/Regulations protected from judicial review
**Originally 13 Acts**: Mainly land reform Acts of various states
**Current status**: **284 Acts** (misused - Acts unrelated to land reforms added)
**Protection**: Acts in Ninth Schedule cannot be challenged for violating FRs
irCoelho2007: **I.R. Coelho v State of Tamil Nadu (2007)** - 9-judge bench
• Acts added to Ninth Schedule **after Apr 24, 1973** (Kesavananda date) can be reviewed for **basic structure** violation
• Acts violating basic structure NOT protected even if in Ninth Schedule
• Judicial review restored to some extent
**Effect**: Curtailed 9th Schedule misuse; Basic structure cannot be violated
frVsDpspAngle: Art 31A, 31B show **Legislature's attempt** to give DPSP (land reforms) priority over FR (property)
**Immediate response** to Champakam case (1951) where SC held FRs prevail
Created **exceptions to FRs** for implementing DPSP goals
Shows **ongoing tension** between individual rights (FR) and social welfare (DPSP)
content.examTips: **Art 31A, 31B**: 1st Amendment 1951. Protect land reforms (DPSP) from FR challenges. Art 31A = land reform laws; Art 31B = Ninth Schedule (284 Acts). **I.R. Coelho (2007)**: Basic structure can be reviewed even for 9th Schedule Acts.

principle: **Harmonious construction**: Interpret FRs and DPSPs **together** to give effect to both
**Not conflict, but complement**: FRs and DPSPs are not enemies; They complement each other
**Granville Austin**: 'FRs are means; DPSPs are ends' - Work together for same goal
**Modern approach**: Courts expand FRs using DPSP goals
judicialTechniques: **1. Art 21 expansion**: SC expanded Art 21 (life & liberty) to include DPSP goals:
• Right to livelihood (DPSP Art 39(a)) read into Art 21 - *Olga Tellis (1985)*
• Right to education (DPSP Art 45) read into Art 21 - *Mohini Jain (1992)* (later became Art 21A via 86th Amendment)
• Right to health (DPSP Art 47) read into Art 21 - *CESCA v Union (1995)*
• Right to environment (DPSP Art 48A) read into Art 21 - *MC Mehta cases*
**2. Using DPSPs to interpret FR scope**: DPSPs guide how FRs should be understood
**3. Upholding laws**: If law balances FR and DPSP, courts uphold it
examples: **Reservation cases**: Balance Art 14, 16 (FR - equality) with Art 46 (DPSP - SC/ST welfare)
• SC upheld reservation as **reasonable classification** under Art 14
• Used DPSP Art 46 to justify exception to equality principle
**Minimum wage laws**: Balance Art 19(1)(g) (FR - freedom of trade) with Art 43 (DPSP - living wage)
• Courts held reasonable restriction on freedom for social welfare
**Environmental laws**: Balance Art 19(1)(g) (trade) with Art 48A (DPSP - environment)
convergence: • Art 45 (free education for children) → Art 21A (FR) via 86th Amendment 2002
**FR expansion**: FRs now include many DPSP goals through judicial interpretation
**Net effect**: Gap between FRs and DPSPs narrowing over time
content.examTips: **Harmonious construction**: Modern approach - balance FRs and DPSPs. Courts expand Art 21 to include DPSP goals (livelihood, education, health, environment). Use DPSPs to interpret FRs. Examples: Olga Tellis (livelihood), Mohini Jain (education), MC Mehta (environment).

articles.title: Right to Property - Biggest FR-DPSP Conflict

background: **Original status**: Right to property was **Fundamental Right** (Art 19(1)(f) and Art 31)
**DPSP goal**: Art 39(b), (c) require equitable distribution, prevent concentration of wealth
**Conflict**: Land reforms, nationalization (DPSP implementation) violated property right (FR)
**Biggest constitutional battle**: Multiple amendments, cases over decades
amendments: **1st Amendment 1951**: Art 31A, 31B added - protect land reforms
**4th Amendment 1955**: Amended Art 31 - compensation requirement relaxed
**25th Amendment 1971**: Art 31(2) amended - 'compensation' changed to 'amount'; Art 31C added
**42nd Amendment 1976**: Property right restrictions; Extended Art 31C to all DPSPs
**44th Amendment 1978**: **Removed property as FR** - Now only legal right (Art 300A)
**Total 8+ amendments** related to property - Most amended FR
keyCase: **Kesavananda Bharati (1973)**: Challenge to 24th, 25th, 29th Amendments (all related to property)
Outcome: Basic structure doctrine; Property NOT basic structure
**Effect**: Property can be heavily regulated for public good (DPSP implementation)
resolution: **Current status**: Art 300A - Property as **legal right** (not FR)
Can be acquired by law; Compensation required but not necessarily market value
**DPSP won**: State can acquire, redistribute property for social welfare without FR challenge
**But not absolute**: Art 300A still requires 'authority of law'; Cannot be arbitrary
significance: Shows **Legislature's determination** to implement DPSP (land reforms) over FR (property)
**Multiple amendments** show difficulty of balancing individual rights vs social welfare
**Final outcome**: Social welfare (DPSP) prevailed over individual property right (FR)
**But**: Judicial review retained - Property acquisition must follow due process
content.examTips: **Property right - biggest FR-DPSP conflict**: Originally FR (Art 19(1)(f), 31). 8+ amendments to balance with DPSP Art 39(b), (c). **44th Amendment 1978** removed as FR → now Art 300A (legal right). Shows DPSP (social welfare) can prevail over FR (individual right) through amendments.

evolution: **1970s (Kesavananda)**: Both important; Balance needed; Both part of basic structure
**1980s (Minerva Mills)**: Two lungs theory; Neither supreme
**1990s onwards**: Integration - FRs expanded to include DPSP goals
currentPrinciples: **1. No hierarchy**: Neither FRs nor DPSPs absolutely supreme
**2. Complementary**: Both work together for constitutional goals
**3. Judicial creativity**: Courts expand FRs using DPSPs as guide
**4. Case-by-case**: Balance determined based on facts of each case
**5. Basic structure**: FR-DPSP balance itself is basic feature - Cannot be destroyed
examples: **Vishaka v State of Rajasthan (1997)**: Used DPSP Art 42 (maternity relief) to create sexual harassment guidelines under Art 21
**Unnikrishnan v State of AP (1993)**: Merged Art 45 (DPSP - education) with Art 21 (FR - life) to create right to education
**Vellore Citizens' Welfare Forum (1996)**: Merged Art 48A (DPSP - environment) with Art 21 (FR) - Sustainable development
**Bandhua Mukti Morcha (1984)**: Used DPSP Art 39(e), (f) to expand Art 21 (dignity of workers)
techniques: **Expansive interpretation of Art 21**: Most important technique
**Reading DPSPs into FRs**: DPSPs guide scope of FRs
**Reasonable classification**: Use DPSP goals to justify FR restrictions (Art 14)
**Public Interest Litigation (PIL)**: Tool to enforce DPSP goals through FR violations
futureDirection: **Converging trend**: Gap between FRs and DPSPs narrowing
**Possibilities**: More DPSPs may become FRs (like Art 45 → 21A)
**Judicial role**: Courts increasingly using DPSPs to expand FRs
**Balance shifts**: Depending on social needs, emphasis changes (individual liberty vs social welfare)
content.examTips: **Modern approach**: Integration of FRs and DPSPs. Courts expand Art 21 using DPSP goals. Examples: Vishaka (Art 42), Unnikrishnan (Art 45), Vellore (Art 48A), Bandhua Mukti (Art 39). PIL tool for enforcement. No hierarchy - complementary.

data.summary: **FR-DPSP Conflicts**: Arise when social welfare (DPSP) requires restricting individual liberty (FR). **Champakam (1951)**: FRs prevail; Led to 1st Amendment. **Kesavananda (1973)**: Basic Structure - balance between FRs and DPSPs is basic feature. **Minerva Mills (1980)**: 'Two lungs' theory - both essential; Art 31C limited to Art 39(b), (c). **Key amendments**: Art 31A, 31B (land reforms); Art 31C (DPSP priority for Art 39(b), (c)). **Property right**: Removed as FR (44th Amendment) - biggest FR-DPSP conflict. **Modern approach**: Integration - Courts expand Art 21 to include DPSP goals (livelihood, education, health, environment). Harmonious construction - complementary not contradictory.
